{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3493140,"name":"Micah","username":"Hyperspace1710","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hyperspace1710/{size}/194547_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-26T18:18:38.516Z","cooked":"

We’re currently testing a belt-driven continuous elevator that uses 2 Kraken X60s and are experiencing a problem when we use m_elevatorRight.setControl(new Follower(m_elevatorLeft.getDeviceID(), true)); to set one motor to follow another. It appears like the motors are fighting each other while we run the elevator up and down despite this code being identical to the code we used to run a cable-driven continuous elevator last year (which worked fine). Our current workaround is to just set power to both motors individually (which also works fine), but I’d prefer to be able to set motors as followers as it makes our code simpler. Has anyone else encountered this problem?

Here’s what it looks like with one motor set as a follower:

The second parameter in new Follower(…) is true if you want the motors to rotate in opposite directions. Try setting that to false.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-01-26T18:23:03.229Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":203,"readers_count":202,"score":60.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":483711,"topic_slug":"talonfx-follower-command-causing-motors-to-fight-each-other","display_username":"Amicus1","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33946,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6995A/Choreo/Monologue"},"post_url":"/t/talonfx-follower-command-causing-motors-to-fight-each-other/483711/2","custom_user_title":"6995A/Choreo/Monologue","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3493149,"name":"Micah","username":"Hyperspace1710","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hyperspace1710/{size}/194547_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-26T18:27:24.579Z","cooked":"

Based on our elevator geometry they need to be rotating in opposite directions for it to move.

we saw similar behaviour last year, also with the same solution of just setting the output individually…

I recall it didnt have the issue at first and this popped up after other code changes, i suspected it may have been disabling unused status signals, maybe one of them was used for the follower.

never got the chance to confirm this for our robot though. did you by any chance experience this with some status signals optimized off?

It took us a bit to figure this out and the docs aren’t clear. Between the Invert settings on the motors config, the Follower’s invert flag, and StrictFollower its not obvious what trumps what.

// Left Is Master
TalonFXConfiguration elevatorLeftCfg = new TalonFXConfiguration();
elevatorLeftCfg.MotorOutput.NeutralMode = NeutralModeValue.Brake;
elevatorLeftCfg.MotorOutput.Inverted = InvertedValue.Clockwise_Positive;
m_elevatorLeftTalonFX.getConfigurator().apply(elevatorLeftCfg);

// Right Is Slave
TalonFXConfiguration elevatorRightCfg = new TalonFXConfiguration();
elevatorRightCfg.MotorOutput.NeutralMode = NeutralModeValue.Brake;
m_elevatorRightTalonFX.getConfigurator().apply(elevatorRightCfg);

m_elevatorRightTalonFX.setControl(new Follower(m_elevatorLeftTalonFX.getDeviceID(), true));
","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-01-30T22:05:10.708Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":163,"readers_count":162,"score":102.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":483711,"topic_slug":"talonfx-follower-command-causing-motors-to-fight-each-other","display_username":"kylelanman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9953,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/talonfx-follower-command-causing-motors-to-fight-each-other/483711/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3497380,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-31T02:03:44.907Z","cooked":"

As is documented in the API docs, when using the regular Follower control request, the invert of the follower is determined by the specified relationship to the leader’s invert. If the second parameter is true, then it will use the opposite of the leader invert, whereas if it is false, then it will use the same invert as the leader. So in that code snippet, false is CW+, and true is CCW+.

On the other hand, with StrictFollower, the follower ignores the leader’s invert, instead using its own invert config.

does a follow request depend on status signals not being optimized/turned off?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-01-31T02:40:04.826Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":141,"readers_count":140,"score":38.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":483711,"topic_slug":"talonfx-follower-command-causing-motors-to-fight-each-other","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":48146,"username":"bhall-ctre","name":"Benjamin Hall","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61239,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/talonfx-follower-command-causing-motors-to-fight-each-other/483711/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3497430,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-31T02:45:06.102Z","cooked":"

Follower requires that the getDutyCycle() (or getTorqueCurrent() if the leader is using a TorqueCurrentFOC request) status signal remains enabled, recommended at least at the default update frequency of 100 Hz.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-01-31T02:45:06.102Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":135,"readers_count":134,"score":47.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":483711,"topic_slug":"talonfx-follower-command-causing-motors-to-fight-each-other","display_username":"Benjamin Hall","primary_group_name":"CTRE","flair_name":"CTRE","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/1/b/1bd2b430e1bb6427d1c6504ff6abcd31de851a6d.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":57,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":61239,"username":"AvocadoPeel","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avocadopeel/{size}/232401_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48146,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics"},"post_url":"/t/talonfx-follower-command-causing-motors-to-fight-each-other/483711/8","custom_user_title":"Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3497502,"name":"kylelanman","username":"kylelanman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kylelanman/{size}/3427_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-31T03:21:25.360Z","cooked":"

Are you referring to this or is there a more thorough explanation?

Phoenix 6

Control Requests

Phoenix 6 provides an extensive list of flexible control modes through the use of strongly-typed control requests. Using Control Requests:,, v5,, Java C++,, v6,, Java C++,,,, Follower Motors:,, v5,...

// m_follower should NOT oppose leader
m_follower.setControl(new Follower(m_leader.getDeviceID(), false));

Its not clear from that if the param passed to follower applies in addition to the MotorConfig or if it is in place of.

// set m_strictFollower to strict-follow m_leader
// strict followers ignore the leader's invert and use their own
m_strictFollower.setControl(new StrictFollower(m_leader.getDeviceID()));

The comment for strict follower you can kinda infer how Follower behaves but our assumption was that the motor config always applied.

I guess I’ll ask the question. Why are their two ways of doing it? It seems like setting the inverts properly in the config and then setting it as a follower is the most straight forward.

I’m also remembering that this spanned multiple shop sessions and that the slave motor was determined to be defective so its possible we landed on multiple combinations that worked and a bad slave motor was adding to the confusion.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-01-31T03:21:25.360Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":127,"readers_count":126,"score":65.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":483711,"topic_slug":"talonfx-follower-command-causing-motors-to-fight-each-other","display_username":"kylelanman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://v6.docs.ctr-electronics.com/en/stable/docs/migration/migration-guide/control-requests-guide.html#follower-motors","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Control Requests","clicks":11}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":48146,"username":"bhall-ctre","name":"Benjamin Hall","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9953,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/talonfx-follower-command-causing-motors-to-fight-each-other/483711/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3497519,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-31T03:32:42.919Z","cooked":"
kylelanman:

Are you referring to this or is there a more thorough explanation?

That’s just the migration guide, I’m referring to the actual API documentation: Follower (CTRE Phoenix 6 Java 25.2.1).

kylelanman:

Why are their two ways of doing it?

Back in Phoenix 5, there were also two ways to do this because we had four possible invert settings: CCW+, CW+, FollowMaster, and OpposeMaster. However, this sometimes caused confusion as to what the invert should be when using followers, and many people didn’t even know you could define it in terms of the leader’s invert.

In Phoenix 6, since invert is now a config, and two of those invert settings don’t make sense outside of following, we decided to split the follower control itself into two. Follower operates in terms of the leader’s invert, which makes sense for most mechanisms: either the motors are the same direction in the gear box or opposite directions. Whereas StrictFollower operates entirely in terms of the invert configs for each motor, which some users still prefer.

kylelanman:

but our assumption was that the motor config always applied

I’m not sure how the invert config could be taken into account, there’s no logical way to do so in conjunction with the boolean for whether to oppose the leader. If I set the leader to CCW, the follower to CW, and say “do not oppose the leader invert”, the only way to do that is to override the follower’s invert with CCW.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-01-31T03:38:07.571Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":119,"readers_count":118,"score":43.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":483711,"topic_slug":"talonfx-follower-command-causing-motors-to-fight-each-other","display_username":"Benjamin Hall","primary_group_name":"CTRE","flair_name":"CTRE","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/1/b/1bd2b430e1bb6427d1c6504ff6abcd31de851a6d.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":57,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://api.ctr-electronics.com/phoenix6/release/java/com/ctre/phoenix6/controls/Follower.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Follower (CTRE Phoenix 6 Java 25.2.1)","clicks":15}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48146,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics"},"post_url":"/t/talonfx-follower-command-causing-motors-to-fight-each-other/483711/10","custom_user_title":"Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3498425,"name":"Micah","username":"Hyperspace1710","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hyperspace1710/{size}/194547_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-31T23:03:42.369Z","cooked":"

Did CTRE change anything with the follower command works at some point in the last year? Does it behave differently from Falcon 500s to Krakens? We’ve tried everything recommended in this thread and nothing has worked. I’m also very confused how code identical to working code used last year isn’t working either.

Here’s the graphs of applied current and voltage with and without the followers respectively:

Applied voltage with/without follower:

IMG_79374032×3024 2.76 MB

IMG_79384032×3024 2.53 MB

Supply current with/without follower:

Nothing should have changed with following in 2025. It’s hard to tell from those graphs what’s going on, as the supply current and motor output graphs don’t cover the same motion. There may also be something else going on here; can you enable our SignalLogger, reproduce the issue, and send the resulting hoot log? You can download the hoot log using Tuner X.

Hello, our team meets exactly the same problem with you…
The Follower control logic of CTRE is not working
We used this logic on separate gear boxes in past seasons and it works perfectly fine in years before 2025.
Actually we saw that great teams like 6328 uses the same logic of follower on separate gear boxes and have a perfect performance… There must be something wrong.
We tested both Falcon and Kraken, both Robot RIO 1, 2, and connecting Canivore. We even tried switching leader and follower, or writing a “follower” logic by ourselves, but things aren’t going better…
How is it going with yours?

We were able to find some example code that worked, but I don’t we ever found out what exactly was causing the problem. I think it the solution was optimizing the CAN bus utilization for both motors (e.g., motor.optimizeBusUtilization(4, 0.1);), and here’s a link to our code for reference.
